title: 108_hr3737
content: The "Pay Compression Relief Act of 2004" is the short title of this Act. References in the Act are considered to be made to title 5, United States Code. Amendments relating to basic pay are included in the Act. The "Pay Compression Relief Act of 2004" makes amendments to basic pay rates for Administrative Law Judges and Contract Appeals Board Members, ensuring that rates do not exceed level III of the Executive Schedule. The "Pay Compression Relief Act of 2004" amends basic pay rates for Administrative Law Judges and Contract Appeals Board Members, ensuring rates do not exceed level III of the Executive Schedule. Adjustments are made in line with General Schedule pay rate adjustments, with regulations to be prescribed by the Office of Personnel Management. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS RELATING TO LOCALITY-BASED COMPARABILITY PAYMENTS. Amendments were made to section 5304 regarding maximums and administrative appeals judges under the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2004. The applicable maximum under the subsection was modified to level II and III of the Executive Schedule for different positions. Additionally, changes were made to subparagraphs within section 5304(h)(1). Amendments were made to section 5304 under the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2004, including redesignating subparagraphs and inserting a new position for administrative appeals judges. Amendments to section 5304 under the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2004 include changes to subparagraph designations and the addition of a new position for administrative appeals judges. Technical and conforming amendments were made to section 5304(h)(2)(B), with adjustments to clauses (i) and (ii). The amendments made by this Act will adjust compensation rates for service performed before and after a specified date, aligning with the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2004. The specified date will be the earlier of the first day of the first pay period at least 90 days after enactment or another date not earlier than enactment. The Office of Personnel Management may determine a date for adjustments to compensation rates, not earlier than the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. The Office of Personnel Management must submit a report to Congress within 6 months of this Act's enactment. The report will include a list of Executive Schedule positions, their pay rates, and the number of individuals in each position. It will also compare pay rates for various positions with Executive Schedule positions. The Office of Personnel Management is required to submit a report to Congress within 6 months of this Act's enactment. The report will include a comparison of pay rates for administrative law judges, administrative appeals judges, and contract appeals board members with rates for judges of district courts and court of appeals. It will also recommend adjustments to Executive Schedule positions based on this comparison and any other pertinent information. The Office of Personnel Management must submit a report to Congress within 6 months of this Act's enactment, comparing pay rates for various positions and recommending adjustments for Executive Schedule positions. The report will include data and methodology used in its preparation. Executive Schedule positions refer to positions with fixed annual pay rates in the executive branch, excluding certain positions like administrative law judges.
